chapter.title: 40 Klebsiella, Enterobacter, Citrobacter, and Selected Other Enterobacteriaceae

sect1.title: 40 Klebsiella, Enterobacter, Citrobacter, and Selected Other Enterobacteriaceae

para.phrase: SANCHITA DAS, VIRGINIA M. PIERCE, AND KAREN M. FRANK

sect1.para: The generaKlebsiella, Enterobacter, Citrobacter, and Cronobacter are commonly encountered in clinical laboratories and cause a range of infections in humans, including bacteremia, meningitis, wound infections, and infections of the respiratory and urinary tracts. Other genera discussed in this chapter include a subset of other Enterobacteriaceae, within the order Enterobacterales, that are less frequently seen in human infections but which may need to be identified when isolated in the clinical laboratory. Genera discussed in this chapter are commonly recovered from plants, animals, and the environment, in addition to human sources. Some of the genera are included in the ESKAPE/ESKAPEE pathogens list (the abbreviation indicating Enterococcus faecium, Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Acinetobacter baumannii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacter spp., and Escherichia coli), a grouping recognized by the Infectious Diseases Society of America because these organisms cause frequent and significant infections and “escape” antimicrobial therapy due to their antimicrobial resistance (1). Other members of the family Enterobacteriaceae and of the order Enterobacterales are detailed in separate chapters of this Manual. This chapter contains information not only on the taxonomy, detection, and identification of these genera but also on the global issue of antimicrobial resistance, which is especially pertinent to this group of organisms.

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The previous orderEnterobacteriales, which included the family Enterobacteriaceae, has been reclassified as the order Enterobacterales ord. nov., consisting of seven families: Enterobacteriaceae, Erwiniaceae fam. nov., Pectobacteriaceae fam. nov., Yersiniaceae fam. nov., Hafniaceae fam. nov., Morganellaceae fam. nov., and Budviciaceae fam. nov. (2). Bacteria in this chapter are shown in the context of their family and order in Fig. 1. The order includes more than 250 species, and the comprehensive comparative genomic analyses used to develop this modified classification included phylogenetic reconstructions based on 1,548 core proteins, 53 ribosomal proteins, and four multilocus sequence analysis proteins, as well as consideration of the overall genome similarity among members of the order (2). In the 1960s, the family Enterobacteriaceae included only 10 genera and 24 species, compared to more than 30 genera and more than 130 species prior to the most recent reclassification. The taxonomic assignment of specific species within the Enterobacteriaceae has undergone extensive revision over many years and has been a matter of debate, as it has been difficult to categorize members of this family into clearly distinguishable phylogenetic groups (3–6).

The frequent reclassification of organisms with clinical significance can lead to confusion for microbiologists, physicians, and regulatory authorities responsible for the monitoring and control of such organisms. The controversy continues regarding the most recently proposed taxonomic classification changes, so additional changes are expected before the next edition of thisManual (4, 7–9). Although this situation is not unique to the Enterobacterales, it is very apparent with this group of organisms because of their clinical and public health importance. Many species that fall within the order Enterobacterales were originally described based on morphological and phenotypic information decades ago; however, genomic analyses have highlighted limitations of the phenotypic categorization.

In addition to phenotypic characteristics, genomic GC content, DNA-DNA hybridization, and 16S rRNA gene sequencing have been used over time to classify the bacteria (10, 11). Multiple methods of classification are required, as the 16S rRNA gene is often unreliable for closely related members of the Enterobacterales due to microheterogeneities within multiple copies of the genes (12, 13). Consequently, it can be impossible to assign an unknown isolate to a specific species with only the 16S rRNA gene sequence, as the sequence may not be unique enough to differentiate one species from another closely related species.

One approach for classification uses combinations of single-copy housekeeping gene regions (alleles or loci) to produce a multilocus sequence analysis (MLSA). Such housekeeping genes must be present within the taxon under study, occur as single-copy genes, and be independent of one another (14). In parallel, many international multilocus sequence typing (MLST) schemes based typically on seven loci have been established and can be accessed via curated centralized databases such as PubMLST (https://pubMLST.org). The application of MLST has led to the recognition of definable sequence types of particular clinical significance, e.g., Escherichia coli ST131 and Klebsiella pneumoniae ST258 (15–18).

figure.title: FIGURE 1 Genera described in this chapter. The selected genera in the family Enterobacteriaceae described here are in boldface and are shown in the context of the entire family and the order Enterobacterales, with the taxonomy accepted at the time of this writing. The five most clinically significant genera from this chapter are marked with asterisks. The phylogenetic lines are not drawn to scale but instead outline the groupings. Adapted from the work of Adeolu et al. with updates from the LPSN website (2, 30).

sect2.para: MLSA of the loci from several housekeeping genes can give better phylogenetic resolution than 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis. The application of MLSA to taxonomic description of members of theEnterobacterales frequently uses only four or five loci, such as a subset of recN, rpoA, rpoB, thdF, infB, atpD, and gyrB (19–22). On occasion, only three loci have been used, but this is not desirable for ideal discrimination. Although the use of such housekeeping genes can result in different, or more discriminatory, phylogenetic classifications than 16S RNA gene sequencing, these may not correspond with data generated by DNA-DNA hybridization or other genomic analyses (13, 23).

The use of whole-genome sequencing (WGS) has led to the development ofin silico alternatives to DNA-DNA hybridization, such as the average nucleotide identity (24). WGS has been critical for the most recent taxonomic revisions, and WGS and/or 16S rRNA sequencing of cultured isolates is becoming accessible to more clinical microbiology laboratories, either as in-house or reference laboratory testing, with a reasonably short turnaround time; thus, revolutionary changes to patient management have been achieved in the past decade (25–29). Although a universal cutoff value to delineate bacterial species does not exist, a DNA-DNA hybridization value of <70% and average nucleotide identity of <95% ± 0.5% have been applied in general.

Some taxonomic changes within theEnterobacteriaceae have occurred since publication of the previous edition of this Manual, including for members of the genera Citrobacter spp., Enterobacter spp., Franconibacter spp., Izhakiella spp., Klebsiella spp., Kluyvera spp., Kosakonia spp., Leclercia spp., Lelliottia spp., Mangrovibacter spp., Phytobacter spp., Pseudocitrobacter spp., and Rosenbergiella spp.; species representing newly described genera within the Enterobacteriaceae have also been published, including Intestinirhabdus alba, Limnobaculum parvum, Pseudescherichia vulneris, Scandinavium goeteborgense, Tenebrionibacter intestinalis, and Tenebrionicola larvae. There will be further taxonomic changes in the future following additional analyses. Table 1 lists the Enterobacteriaceae discussed in this chapter; some species will be unfamiliar to many clinical microbiologists, as they may not be associated with human infections. As nomenclature changes over time, updates can be found at the List of Prokaryotic Names with Standing in Nomenclature (LPSN) website (http://www.bacterio.net/) (30).

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE GENERA
sect2.para: Members belonging to the orderEnterobacterales are Gram-negative, facultative anaerobic rods or coccobacilli ranging from about 0.3 to 1.0 μm wide and 0.6 to 6.0 μm long. They ferment glucose with the production of various end products depending upon the species, as determined using the methyl red and Voges-Proskauer tests (31). Typically, they are oxidase negative, with the exceptions of Plesiomonas shigelloides (discussed in chapter 41), Franconibacter, and Siccibacter (32), and they are non-spore forming. Growth parameters typically include temperatures of 18 to 47°C, a pH range of 4.0 to 8.0, and salt concentrations of 0 to 5%. Motility is variable and may be attributed to uniformly distributed or polar flagella. The selected Enterobacteriaceae discussed in this chapter generally grow well on routine culture media, such as blood agar and MacConkey agar, at 35°C. A few organisms grow at lower temperatures, as discussed in species-specific paragraphs. Strains from all genera may grow as mucoid or rough colonies. Klebsiella, Raoultella, and Enterobacter spp. are encapsulated. Most Citrobacter and Enterobacter species are motile, and most Klebsiella and Raoultella species are nonmotile, but there are exceptions, as discussed in the genus-specific paragraphs.

sect2.para: aCSF, cerebrospinal fluid; RT, respiratory tract; UT, urinary tract; GI, gastrointestinal.

Pigment production is restricted to a few genera ofEnterobacteriaceae. Yellow pigment-producing organisms include ~80% of strains in the genus Cronobacter and Leclercia adecarboxylata. Yellow pigment production may be enhanced by incubation at 25°C as opposed to 37°C. Weak pigment producers may be most easily noted by placing the agar plate growth on a bench in sunlight for a short period. Auxotrophic strains of these organisms, which require a specific growth substance beyond the minimum required for normal metabolism, are uncommonly recovered from clinical specimens. However, cysteine-requiring urinary isolates of K. pneumoniae, which grow as pinpoint colonies on routine media, do occur (33). When encountered, these strains require supplementation of biochemical media or commercial identification systems with cysteine for accurate identification. Klebsiella granulomatis is fastidious and culturable only by in vitro cell culture techniques not usually employed by routine clinical microbiology laboratories.

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY, TRANSMISSION, AND CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: TheEnterobacterales are widely distributed throughout the environment (Table 1). Many species of the genera in Table 1 are commonly recognized pathogens throughout the world (34). They consistently rank among the top 10 organisms seen in health care-associated infections (35–37). Klebsiella and Enterobacter spp. are among the most common pathogens associated with health care-associated infections (38). The data reported to the National Healthcare Safety Network at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention showed that of >311,000 health care-associated infections in adults, Klebsiella spp. were responsible for about 9% and Enterobacter spp. for almost 5% (39). Of the >19,000 pediatric health care-associated infections, Klebsiella spp. caused more than 9% and Enterobacter spp. caused 6.5% (40). Klebsiella pneumoniae was responsible for 7% of pediatric bloodstream infections in a study of 33 medical centers from 2014 to 2018 (41). A study of the global burden of antimicrobial resistance reported that K. pneumoniae is one of the six leading pathogens causing death associated with antimicrobial resistance (42). K. pneumoniae was also one of four organisms responsible for duodenoscope-associated infections in a study analyzing multiple countries, including the United States, European countries, and China. The resulting infections led to changes in the design, cleaning, and handling of endoscopes (43). European data on infection rates, which are similar to those above, can be obtained from the European Centres for Disease Prevention and Control (https://ecdc.europa.eu/en). Infection rates for individual European countries can be obtained from the appropriate regulatory health authority, such as Public Health England (https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/public-health-england). Carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae have been demonstrated to cause increased mortality in several studies (44–48).

sect1.title: Klebsiella and Raoultella
sect1.para: Klebsiella spp. are carried in the nasopharynx and colon, and feces are regarded as a significant source of patient infections (49–51). K. pneumoniae bloodstream infection rates are 1.5 times greater during the warmest months of the year (52). These rates may reflect increased fecal carriage in humans (50), which, in turn, is a reflection of increased organisms in the environment during warm months. This has important implications because colonized patients have a four-fold-increased risk of infection over noncarriers. Similar isolation rate increases are not reported with Enterobacter or Serratia spp. (52).

K. pneumoniae is a significant pathogen in both community and hospital settings. The clinical challenge posed by this organism has intensified with the emergence of two types of K. pneumoniae, carbapenem-resistant K. pneumoniae (CRKP) and hypervirulent K. pneumoniae (HvKP), as well as strains that are both carbapenem-resistant and hypervirulent. The initial strain type of CRKP and the strain type commonly associated with outbreaks is ST258 (53). Over time, however, transmission of blaKPC has led to diversification of CRKP to such an extent that some regions report polyclonality at rates approaching 60% (54). Strains of K. pneumoniae can also undergo interstrain recombination, resulting in de novo strain types of CRKP (55); furthermore, mechanisms of carbapenem resistance other than blaKPC, including blaNDM and blaOXA-48-like carbapenemases, are increasingly identified in K. pneumoniae (56). Globally, CRKP has become a leading cause of death attributable to antimicrobial resistance (42).

HvKP is broadly defined as anyK. pneumoniae strain which has acquired a plasmid that encodes enhanced capsule production and expression of siderophores, such as salmochelin and aerobactin (57). Typically, these strains are of capsular type K1 or K2, but hypervirulence is neither universal among nor unique to K. pneumoniae strains with these capsule types. To date, HvKP infections have been reported predominantly from the Asian Pacific Rim although descriptions from other parts of the world are increasing (57–60). Compared to classical K. pneumoniae, HvKP strains are more likely to cause invasive infections. Infections may present with multiple sites of involvement or may be associated with subsequent bacteremic metastasis, a feature unusual in infections caused by other Enterobacteriaceae. The hallmark clinical manifestation of HvKP infection is liver abscess, but infections involving other anatomic sites have been described, including endophthalmitis, meningitis, brain abscess, splenic abscess, necrotizing fasciitis, and psoas abscess (57).

Although less frequent, HvKP strains are capable of acquiring plasmids or other elements that lead to multidrug resistance (61); likewise, multidrug resistant classical K. pneumoniae strains can acquire a HvKP virulence plasmid (62, 63). Alarmingly, a recent analysis of global CRKP genome sequences showed a substantial increase in the prevalence of genes associated with hypervirulence between 2010 and 2019 (64). A hypermucoviscous phenotype, crudely shown by a positive string test, may be a sign for the laboratory worker to consider a hypervirulent strain (65); however, hypermucoviscosity is neither sensitive nor specific as a test for hypervirulence (66). Molecular assays for biomarkers, such as siderophore production or capsule production, might prove to be more accurate for the differentiation of HvKP from classical K. pneumoniae but have not been developed for routine use by clinical laboratories.

A majority ofK. pneumoniae isolates encountered in the clinical laboratory belong to Klebsiella pneumoniae subsp. pneumoniae. Two additional subspecies of K. pneumoniae are K. pneumoniae subsp. rhinoscleromatis and K. pneumoniae subsp. ozaenae; these were formerly the distinct species K. rhinoscleromatis and K. ozaenae but were later reclassified as subspecies of K. pneumoniae. These organisms have been associated with specific chronic infectious diseases, i.e., rhinoscleroma and atrophic rhinitis (ozena), respectively (67–69). While they are distinguishable biochemically, matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) systems may not differentiate subspecies of K. pneumoniae. To overcome this limitation, they can be reported as Klebsiella pneumoniae complex. Conversely, two phylogroups previously considered within K. pneumoniae but distinguished through analysis of the parC and gyrA genes have been reclassified as distinct species: K. variicola (KpIII) and K. quasipneumoniae (KpII), of which there are two subspecies, K. quasipneumoniae subsp. quasipneumoniae and K. quasipneumoniae subsp. similipneumoniae (70, 71). Our understanding of the epidemiology and clinical manifestations of infections caused by these species is likely limited by their frequent misidentification as K. pneumoniae (72–74). The species have overlapping phenotypic and biochemical features, and inclusion of mislabeled sequences in publicly available genomic databases and research publications has perpetuated misidentification of K. variicola and K. quasipneumoniae by newly developed assays. Improved identification of K. variicola, such as that which has occurred through updates to MALDI-TOF MS databases, has recently led to recognition of this species as a pathogen responsible for bloodstream infections, pneumonia, and urinary tract infections, including in immunocompromised individuals (74).

K. oxytoca is less frequently isolated than K. pneumoniae but is likewise an important cause of community-acquired and health care-associated infections, including bloodstream infections, pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and intra-abdominal infections. Sequence variation among chromosomal blaOXY genes has been used to divide K. oxytoca isolates into phylogroups. Although WGS-based analyses suggest that K. oxytoca is actually a complex composed of nine distinct species, identification methods routinely used in clinical laboratories (including commercial microbial identification systems relying on biochemical reactions, MALDI-TOF MS, and 16S rRNA gene sequencing) lack sufficient resolution to reliably distinguish them; at this time, therefore, they are described as a single species in this chapter (75). K. oxytoca strains carrying a chromosomally encoded heat-labile cytotoxin have been recognized as a cause of antibiotic-associated hemorrhagic colitis (75–77). Antibiotic-associated hemorrhagic colitis, associated with the use of β-lactam antibiotics, generally resolves spontaneously with the withdrawal of the contributing antibiotic.

Klebsiella aerogenes was reclassified from the previous name Enterobacter aerogenes in 2017 (78). Inclusion of this organism within the genus Klebsiella was proposed as early as 1971 based on its phenotypic characteristics; more recent work using WGS supported the appropriateness of this taxonomic revision. Clinical laboratories should be aware of the potential for implementation of this taxonomic update to cause confusion among clinicians, particularly regarding differences between the generally predicted antimicrobial susceptibility patterns and resistance mechanisms of the genera Klebsiella and Enterobacter. A notable consideration is the baseline chromosomal AmpC β-lactamase production and inducible AmpC β-lactamase derepression exhibited by K. aerogenes, features shared by Enterobacter spp. but not other Klebsiella spp. K. aerogenes is ubiquitous in the environment and often isolated as a cause of nosocomial infection, including among immunocompromised individuals and patients admitted to intensive care units (79).

K. granulomatis is the agent of donovanosis or granuloma inguinale, a disease characterized by painless, slowly progressive, vascular genital ulcers (80, 81). Extragenital infection, through contiguous spread to the pelvis or dissemination to other sites, rarely occurs (82, 83). Granuloma inguinale occurs predominantly in tropical countries and is thought to be sexually transmitted, with humans as the only known reservoir.

Raoultella ornithinolytica, Raoultella planticola, and Raoultella terrigena are another group of organisms similar to K. pneumoniae that have been reclassified. Although Raoultella isolates share biochemical characteristics with K. pneumoniae, they are distinguished based on their ability to grow at 10°C and utilize L-sorbose (84). In addition, they can be differentiated using MALDI-TOF MS (85), although some isolates may be identified as the combined report of K. oxytoca/R. ornithinolytica using current databases. In European studies, 3.5% to 19% of clinical strains initially identified as Klebsiella were R. planticola, while in U.S. and Brazilian surveys of 436 and 122 strains, respectively, only one isolate in each was identified as R. planticola, suggesting that the prevalence of these species may differ geographically (86–88). In recent years, reports of R. ornithinolytica and R. planticola infections in humans have increased, with the range of described clinical syndromes similar to those caused by K. pneumoniae (89, 90). R. terrigena is an aquatic and soil organism; reports of human infections have been less frequent. The first reported human infection by this organism was in 2007; a 45-year-old patient developed endocarditis due to R. terrigena after liver transplantation (91).

sect1.title: Enterobacter
sect1.para: Since the early 1970s, organisms once calledEnterobacter have been reclassified into multiple new genera that are in multiple families, including but not limited to Klebsiella, Pantoea, Lelliottia, Kosakonia, Pluralibacter, Franconibacter, Kluyvera, Cronobacter, and Siccibacter (4). At the time of this chapter revision, there are 22 species of Enterobacter, per the LPSN website: Enterobacter asburiae, E. bugandensis, E. cancerogenus, E. chengduensis, E. chuandaensis, E. cloacae, E. dykesii, E. hormaechei, E. huaxiensis, E. kobei, E. ludwigii, E. mori, E. oligotrophicus, E. quasihormaechei, E. quasimori, E. quasiroggenkampii, E. roggenkampii, E. siamensis, E. sichuanensis, E. soli, E. vonholyi, and E. wuhouensis. Additional unnamed genomospecies may join the genus in the future (27, 92). The taxonomy will undoubtedly be modified with additional sequencing analysis. Although this is a large number of species, the clinical microbiologist most often encounters E. cloacae and E. hormaechei in clinical specimens. These two species are further divided into subspecies, E. cloacae subsp. cloacae and E. cloacae subsp. dissolvens, and E. hormaechei subsp. hoffmannii, E. hormaechei subsp. hormaechei, E. hormaechei subsp. oharae, E. hormaechei subsp. steigerwaltii, and E. hormaechei subsp. xiangfangensis.

Enterobacter spp. are opportunistic pathogens that are found in the natural environment in habitats such as water, sewage, vegetables, and soil. They are also commensal bacteria in the human gastrointestinal tract (79). Enterobacter spp. also occur in dairy products, meat, hospital environments, and the skin and intestinal tracts of animals (78). Enterobacter is the third most common pathogenic genus of the family Enterobacteriaceae, after Escherichia and Klebsiella (27, 92). Nosocomial infections due to Enterobacter spp. are often seen in immunocompromised patients, patients with diabetes mellitus, burn patients, and those undergoing invasive procedures. Nosocomial Enterobacter colonization and infection have been associated with contaminated parenteral nutrition, humidifiers, and respiratory therapy equipment (79). This genus is associated with septicemia, wounds, urinary tract infections, meningitis, and abdominal infections (79). Clinical consequences of Enterobacter infection are severe, and bloodstream infections with E. cloacae complex (defined in the description of identification methods) have a higher reported mortality than those due to K. aerogenes (79). The recently described species E. bugandensis is reported to be highly pathogenic with well-developed virulence mechanisms and plasmid-mediated antimicrobial resistance (79). Time will tell if this species becomes more commonly recovered from patients.

Treatment ofEnterobacter sp. infections can be challenging, as many strains are multidrug resistant as a result of intrinsic resistance due to chromosomal AmpC β-lactamase, as well as plasmid-based carriage of antibiotic resistance. Enterobacter spp. may carry extended-spectrum β-lactamases, such as TEM, SHV, and CTX-M, and may carry carbapenemases. They may also have plasmid-mediated resistance to aminoglycosides and fluoroquinolones. They have decreased susceptibility to polymyxins, more often due to chromosomally mediated changes in lipopolysaccharides in the membrane utilizing the PhoP-PhoQ two-component system than to plasmid-mediated mcr gene mechanisms (27, 92). The frequent heteroresistance seen for polymyxins in Enterobacter results in the appearance of skipped wells in broth microdilution and yields incorrect susceptibility results in the clinical laboratory (93–95).

TheEnterobacter spp. have multiple mechanisms of resistance, including the ability to regulate expression of enzymes (such as β-lactamase) and membrane transporters (such as porins and efflux pumps) via local and global regulatory genes (79). Enterobacter spp. are commonly treated with carbapenems (93). The delineation and recognition of species within this genus remain dynamic, and this affects the reliability of our understanding of the ecology and epidemiology of a given Enterobacter sp. Moreover, the importance of updating taxonomy is highlighted by a bacteremia case thought to have been caused by E. cloacae (identified by VITEK 2); the organism was later classified as the pathogen Kosakonia radicincitans using genetic methods (96). The significance of this finding is that, unlike E. cloacae, Kosakonia spp. do not harbor the chromosomal AmpC β-lactamases that limit treatment options in Enterobacter infections, thereby allowing more appropriate, targeted therapy.

In addition toEnterobacter spp. (and Klebsiella aerogenes which was formerly E. aerogenes), other “SPICE/MYSPACE” organisms (acronyms representing organisms harboring chromosomal AmpC β-lactamases) include Serratia, Pseudomonas, Citrobacter, Morganella, Yersinia, Providencia, and Aeromonas spp. The diverse virulence mechanisms in Enterobacter include motility, biofilm formation, and adhesion. Some strains can also have endotoxins, enterotoxins, a type III secretion system, the ability to chelate iron, and a chromosomal high-pathogenicity island (97, 98). A number of Enterobacter sequence types have been associated with global dissemination and/or increased resistance; however, the sequence types are determined not for routine clinical diagnostics but instead for outbreak investigations and research of bacterial pathogenesis (92, 99).

sect1.title: Cronobacter
sect1.para: The genusCronobacter (proposed as a genus in 2008 and formerly called Enterobacter sakazakii [101]), in the family Enterobacteriaceae, currently contains seven species: Cronobacter condimenti, C. dublinensis, C. malonaticus, C. muytjensii, C. sakazakii, C. turicensis, and C. universalis (100–103). The genus Cronobacter previously included C. helveticus, C. pulveris, and C. zurichensis, which were formerly known as Enterobacter helveticus, Enterobacter pulveris, and Enterobacter turicensis. These have been taxonomically reassigned to Franconibacter helveticus, Franconibacter pulveris, and Siccibacter turicensis (32). Of these, C. sakazakii and C. malonaticus are the species most frequently isolated from clinical samples (104, 105), with C. sakazakii predominating in neonatal infections and C. malonaticus in adult infections. Cronobacter spp. are ubiquitous in the environment, having a proposed association with plants, and are documented to contaminate food (106).

Of the reported cases ofC. sakazakii, 67% were in neonates, and it is notable that there have been increasing numbers of reports of infections in full-term neonates (107). Although not common, C. sakazakii has been associated with severe cases of neonatal meningitis, bacteremia, and necrotizing enterocolitis with mortality rates of 38 to 80% (107, 108). The reported incidence is believed to be underestimated, because Cronobacter infection is not a reportable disease (107). In these cases, brain abscesses may be seen in just under half of the cases reported (4). Risk of illness is higher in those receiving powdered infant formula (79% of cases) (107, 109), and the reported incidence has increased over the past 20 years (4, 107). In February 2022, multiple brands of powdered infant formula were recalled due to the illness and deaths of a number of infants (https://www.cdc.gov/cronobacter/outbreaks/infant-formula.html).

C. sakazakii has been recovered from other food products, and its ability to grow at refrigeration temperatures, its salt tolerance, and resistance to desiccation and acid conditions may contribute to this finding (108, 110, 111). Recently, C. sakazakii was implicated in a food-borne outbreak in healthy adolescents (112). This species is the only member of the genus, apart from some strains of C. turicensis, to utilize sialic acid (2-keto-3-deoxy-5-acetamido-D-glycero-D-galacto-nonulosonic acid). This may contribute to its propensity to cause neonatal and infant infections, because sialic acid is found in breast milk, infant formula, mucin, and gangliosides in the brain (113).

Numerous proposed virulence factors ofC. sakazakii include the outer membrane proteins OmpA and OmpX, Zpx (a metalloprotease), Cpa (which confers serum resistance), the iuc iron acquisition system, the type III hemolysin Hly, a heat-stable enterotoxin, sfp (which encodes fimbriae), and the recently added CklR, a LysR-type regulator that activates expression of the suf Fe-S cluster biosynthesis operon for resistance to oxidative stress (114, 115). A recent report suggested that Cronobacter spp. may survive in macrophages in a viable-but-nonculturable state and contribute to disease severity (116). Limited studies to date indicate that C. malonaticus may predominate in adult infections and may be carried in the laryngopharynx (117). Isolates of Cronobacter spp. may not be identified to the species level in some clinical laboratories due to a lack of discriminatory biochemical tests. One identification method is DNA sequence analysis of the fusA and rpoB genes, for which an open-access MLST database is available (http://pubMLST.org/cronobacter). The recognition and expansion of the genus Cronobacter have caused much confusion in the literature. Two common mistakes are (i) referring to all pre-2007 E. sakazakii isolates as C. sakazakii, and (ii) the use of commercially available biochemical kits with supporting databases that use the name E. sakazakii and do not encompass all the species in the genus Cronobacter. Laboratory-developed databases suggest that it is possible to distinguish between Franconibacter, Siccibacter, and Cronobacter spp. and to identify Franconibacter and Siccibacter to the species level (118). However, such databases are not widely available, and labs should remain aware of the possibility that these organisms may be misidentified using some of the current identification systems.

sect1.title: Lelliottia, Pluralibacter, and Kosakonia
sect1.para: The genusLelliottia was formed in 2013 with reclassification of Enterobacter nimipressuralis and Enterobacter amnigenus as Lelliottia nimipressuralis and L. amnigena, respectively (101). L. jeotgali and L. aquatilis were later published as novel species of the genus and were subsequently determined to belong to a single species, L. jeotgali (119). Enterobacter gergoviae and Enterobacter pyrinus have been transferred to the new genus Pluralibacter as Pluralibacter gergoviae and P. pyrinus, respectively. Pathogenicity has been most firmly established for L. amnigena and P. gergoviae; a bloodstream isolate of L. amnigena harboring blaKPC and rmtB genes on a single plasmid has been reported, as have clinical isolates of E. gergoviae harboring blaKPC, blaNDM, or blaIMP (120–126). The new genus Kosakonia includes the former species Enterobacter cowanii, E. radicincitans, E. oryzae, E. arachidis, E. sacchari, E. oryziphilus, and E. oryzendophyticus; these are now known as Kosakonia cowanii, Kosakonia radicincitans, etc. (101, 127). Apart from K. cowanii, originally obtained from clinical samples, and K. radicincitans, which has been reported as a cause of bacteremia, members of the genus Kosakonia are most frequently associated with plants. The generation of reactive oxygen species by K. cowanii in the Anopheles gambiae mosquito midgut has been associated with resistance of the mosquito to Plasmodium falciparum infection (128).

sect1.title: Citrobacter
sect1.para: Citrobacter spp. are primarily opportunistic pathogens that can cause serious infections in individuals with underlying conditions. They are frequently encountered in health care settings and are an important cause of nosocomial infections in neonates and immunocompromised patients (129). Citrobacter spp. are implicated in urinary tract infections, superficial wound infections, respiratory tract infections, intra-abdominal infections, bacteremia, endocarditis, meningitis, brain abscess, and sepsis. The organisms are ubiquitous and can be isolated from soil, water, and food as well as the intestinal tracts of humans and animals. Citrobacter spp. are primarily inhabitants of the intestinal tract, and their presence in the environment may reflect fecal excretion by humans and animals; the natural habitats of some of the newly described Citrobacter spp. remain to be determined.

The genusCitrobacter contains 16 species, of which four are most involved in hospital infections: Citrobacter freundii, C. koseri, and less commonly C. braakii and C. farmeri. Significant Citrobacter infections may be health care associated or community acquired. Patients are usually older adults (≥65 years) and more often males, and the urinary tract is the most common site of infection (130, 131). One-third to one-half of Citrobacter infections, including bloodstream infections, are polymicrobial. Polymicrobial infections, specifically bacteremia, are associated with higher mortality rates (18% to 50%) and longer hospital stays (130, 131). Meningitis is almost exclusively associated with C. koseri and involves children <2 months of age, with the highest onset rates recorded in neonates with a mean age of 7 days (132). Brain abscesses occur in 75% of infected infants, and neurological defects are common sequelae in surviving infants. The most prominent risk factor is prior colonization; during outbreaks, colonization rates of 27% have been noted, versus a typical rate of <1% (133, 134). Person-to-person spread by hospital personnel and, less often, from mother to offspring is the most likely source of infection (135). A few outbreaks have been attributed to clonal spread of antimicrobial-resistant Citrobacter spp. in hospitals (136–138). Sampling of inanimate or environmental reservoirs in hospitals usually fails to yield Citrobacter spp. Other Citrobacter spp., including C. gillenii and C. murliniae, have been found in human clinical, animal, food, and environmental specimens (139, 140). C. europaeus and C. pasteurii have been isolated from patients with diarrhea (141, 142). C. freundii has been implicated in sporadic infantile diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome. This has been attributed to virulence factors homologous, or identical, to those described in E. coli pathotypes (Shiga toxin stx2) (143). It is debated whether this is horizontal transmission of virulence factors from E. coli or an isolated event (4). Rare association of invasive infections such as osteomyelitis, arthritis, and peritonitis have been reported with C. amalonaticus, which is sometimes isolated from urine specimens (144, 145). However, the role of many Citrobacter spp. in human infections remains unclear, because reports in the literature are insufficient to determine either clinical significance in humans or potential reservoirs for infection. C. rodentium causes murine colonic hyperplasia, which is self-limiting in adult mice but causes significant morbidity and mortality in infant mice in mouse colony outbreaks (146). The organism is used in mice as a surrogate model for enteropathogenic E. coli and enterohemorrhagic E. coli infections in humans. More recently, C. rodentium has been utilized to study the gut-brain axis and the role of neurotransmitters in intestinal infections (147).

sect1.title: Pseudocitrobacter
sect1.para: The new genusPseudocitrobacter was first described in 2014 based on phylogenetic analysis of 16S rRNA genes of four fecal isolates from hospitalized patients and outpatients attending military hospitals in Pakistan (148). Initially the strains were phenotypically identified as Citrobacter spp. However, 16S rRNA gene sequence comparison showed that the strains formed a separate cluster with only 97% to 98.3% identity with members of the genera Citrobacter, Kluyvera, Pantoea, Enterobacter, and Raoultella. MLSA of the recN, rpoA, thdF, and rpoB genes and analysis of their respective amino acid sequences also demonstrated that the strains were in unique clusters compared with the remaining Enterobacterales. DNA-DNA hybridization supported the recognition of the new genus, which included Pseudocitrobacter faecalis and Pseudocitrobacter anthropi. A third new species, Pseudocitrobacter vendiensis, was isolated during surveillance screen from a patient in Denmark and showed 91% average nucleotide identity with P. faecalis and P. anthropi. Based on whole-genome sequencing analysis, the core genome of the three species form a monophyletic cluster (149). The average nucleotide identity to the type strains of the related genera Klebsiella, Kluyvera, Trabulsiella, Raoultella, and Yokenella was below 81%. These species differ in their fermentation of raffinose and D-mannitol and in the utilization of N-acetylglucosamine and arbutin. The species described include several strains that were found to carry blaNDM-1 as well as blaKPC, though the clinical significance of infections with Pseudocitrobacter spp. has not been well established to date.

sect1.title: Other Enterobacteriaceae
sect1.para: One well-described phenomenon associated with the widespread adoption of MALDI-TOF MS as a primary method of identification is the dramatic increase of “rare” or “infrequent” causes of infection. These organisms, which includeButtiauxella spp., Cedecea spp., Enterobacillus tribolii, Franconibacter spp., Gibbsiella spp., Intestinirhabdus alba, Izhakiella spp., Kluyvera spp., Leclercia spp., Limnobaculum parvum, Mangrovibacter spp., Phytobacter spp., Pseudescherichia vulneris, Rosenbergiella spp., Saccharobacter fermentatus, Scandinavium goeteborgense, Shimwellia spp., Siccibacter spp., Tenebrionibacter intestinalis, Tenebrionicola larvae, Trabulsiella spp., and Yokenella regensburgei, are primarily opportunistic pathogens in compromised patients, are present as transients or commensals in clinical specimens, or have been recovered only from the environment (4). The environmental niches of these Enterobacteriaceae include vegetation, insects, aquatic habitats, and the gastrointestinal tracts of vertebrate animals (4, 150–155). Some of the more frequently encountered organisms are Kluyvera spp. and L. adecarboxylata. Kluyvera infections occur in immunocompetent and immunosuppressed patients of all age groups (156–158). The organism is isolated from a broad spectrum of sources, including blood, tissue, urine, cerebrospinal fluid, and peritoneal fluid, although urinary tract and bloodstream infections are most frequent. When strains are identified to the species level, Kluyvera ascorbata accounts for the largest number of infections. Recent reports have described the isolation and identification of L. adecarboxylata from a variety of clinical infections (159–162).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: The organisms covered in this chapter are, in general, readily isolated from clinical material, and the principles in the chapterSpecimen Collection, Transport, and Processing: Bacteriology of this Manual are applicable. Most Enterobacteriaceae survive in culture deeps at −70°C for at least one year. Long-term preservation methods as recommended in the chapter Procedures for the Storage of Microorganisms of this Manual work well for these organisms.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: The clinically relevant strains ofEnterobacteriaceae covered in this chapter may be isolated from a variety of specimen types. In general, these organisms grow well on commonly used laboratory media and present little difficulty with regard to isolation from sterile body sites. Isolation from nonsterile body or environmental sites may require selective media to inhibit the growth of Gram-positive bacteria and yeasts. Selective media can also prevent swarming of Proteus and limit the spread of mucoid colonies, which reduces overgrowth of pathogenic colonies of interest. Additionally, growth on some selective media can be used to inoculate antimicrobial susceptibility tests directly without subculture. On highly selective media designed for isolation of pathogens from gastrointestinal specimens, some genera covered in this chapter that are lactose or sucrose fermenters give the appearance of normal biota; of note, Citrobacter may produce H2S and, if fermentation of lactose is slow, resemble Salmonella. Specialized chromogenic media perform comparably to conventional media for the detection of urinary tract pathogens covered in this chapter and can reliably replace MacConkey and blood agars (163, 164). As highly automated systems that employ artificial intelligence become increasingly common in clinical microbiology laboratories, chromogenic media may also facilitate analysis of agar plate digital images (165).

In contrast to the otherEnterobacteriaceae covered here, the intracellular bacterium K. granulomatis does not grow on conventional laboratory media but has been grown in HEp-2 monolayers (166). Detection of Donovan bodies from tissue crush preparation smears or biopsy specimens using the Giemsa or Wright stain is the method most commonly used to detect this organism. However, these pleomorphic, bipolar-staining bodies shaped like a closed safety pin are not always present and are not reliable for diagnosis. There are no FDA-cleared assays for the detection of K. granulomatis DNA, but molecular assays might be useful for the detection of this pathogen (83).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: Many laboratories are now using MALDI-TOF MS for identification, with minimal use of biochemical reactions for routine cultures (167, 168). Identifications via mass spectrometry are dependent on the database available, so improvements and expansions are frequently made to both manufacturer and in-house databases. Most commonly isolated Enterobacteriaceae genera are included in both the Bruker and bioMérieux FDA-cleared mass spectrometry databases, but species may be combined into groups or complexes, and not all genera are included. The research-use-only databases are more extensive, but additional in-house validation is required. Some laboratories automatically resort to 16S rRNA gene sequencing when the identification from the mass spectrometry instrument is ambiguous (25), although the species resolution of MALDI-TOF MS may actually exceed that of partial 16S rRNA sequencing for some closely related Enterobacteriaceae (169). However, biochemical reactions are incorporated into several automated and manual systems that are still used by many clinical laboratories. The biochemical tests most useful for distinguishing members covered in this chapter are outlined in Tables 2 through 5.

It should be noted that identification problems arising from the use of commercial phenotyping systems vary with each genus. The percentage of correct identifications for many commercial systems increases significantly when additional biochemical tests are performed on organisms with “low-probability” identifications. Even when unusualEnterobacteriaceae covered in this chapter are included in commercial system databases, the number of strains available to use in challenge studies may be limited; therefore, caution is warranted when these systems are used to identify uncommon organisms (170). A comprehensive review of manual and automated phenotypic/biochemical systems for the identification of bacteria in clinical laboratories was published in 2005 (170). The review lists the component substrates used and the additional reagents that are needed, if any, as well as quality control, database content, accuracy of identification, important features of each automated identification system, and published evaluations, among other information, for each commercial phenotypic system; however, updated nomenclature would not be included in that report, and the isolate sets historically used to define the biochemical features of certain organisms or to study the accuracy of commercial phenotypic identification systems may have included strains that would currently be identified as members of other species. Even with the newer identification systems, including those employing MALDI-TOF MS, the clinical laboratory should not rely solely on the identification provided by commercial systems but should rather consider colony morphology, susceptibility test data, and anatomic site of isolation.

sect1.title: Klebsiella and Raoultella
sect1.para: K. aerogenes is motile, while K. oxytoca, K. pneumoniae, and Raoultella spp. are nonmotile. Indole production is useful in differentiation between organisms in these genera; K. oxytoca, R. ornithinolytica, and a subset of R. planticola are positive for indole production, whereas K. pneumoniae, K. aerogenes, and R. terrigena are indole negative (171). K. aerogenes and R. ornithinolytica are ornithine decarboxylase (ODC) positive, while K. pneumoniae, K. oxytoca, R. planticola, and R. terrigena are generally ODC negative. K. pneumoniae subsp. pneumoniae and K. oxytoca hydrolyze urea, while K. aerogenes does not. The Voges-Proskauer (VP) test is positive in Klebsiella spp., except for K. pneumoniae subsp. ozaenae and K. pneumoniae subsp. rhinoscleromatis; Raoultella spp. are also usually VP positive, although results for R. ornithinolytica are variable. Malonate and o-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactopyranoside (ONPG) reactions may also be useful in discriminating the subspecies of K. pneumoniae. Brisse and colleagues (67) described key biochemicals to potentially differentiate K. quasipneumoniae, K. pneumoniae, and K. variicola: adonitol, L-sorbose, 3-phenylpropionate, 5-keto-D-gluconate, and tricarballylic acid. Of those reactions, K. pneumoniae was positive only for adonitol. K. variicola was negative for adonitol and 3-phenylpropionate and positive for the other three, while K. quasipneumoniae was positive for tricarballylic acid, negative for 5-keto-D-gluconate, and variable for the other three (67). Subsequent work, however, has shown that a subset of K. variicola strains ferment adonitol (86), so this biochemical reaction cannot definitively be used to differentiate these species.

MALDI-TOF MS using currently available databases may also not reliably differentiate all isolates ofK. pneumoniae, K. variicola, and K. quasipneumoniae, and so sequencing-based strategies may be needed. MALDI-TOF MS systems can generally distinguish Raoultella spp. from Klebsiella spp. (although some isolates may be identified as K. oxytoca/R. ornithinolytica using current databases) and outperform commercial biochemical identification systems at distinguishing between the species in the genus. R. planticola and R. terrigena require temperature growth and carbon assimilation tests to phenotypically distinguish them from Klebsiella spp. (84). R. terrigena can be distinguished from R. planticola by fermentation of D-melezitose.

sect1.title: Enterobacter
sect1.para: Enterobacter spp. display an acid/acid result with significant gas production on Kligler iron agar. They are mobile via evenly distributed flagella. They have characteristics very similar to those of Klebsiella pneumoniae/K. oxytoca, except that they are motile and ornithine positive. K. aerogenes, which was removed from the genus Enterobacter, shares with E. cloacae the properties of motility and ornithine decarboxylase while lacking urease, which is seen in the two Klebsiella species. Because of the genetic heterogeneity in several species, members of the genera Enterobacter present a challenge for some commercial phenotypic identification systems (4, 98). E. ludwigii and E. hormaechei can be distinguished from E. cloacae by growth on 3-O-methyl-D-glucopyranose and putrescine and on 3-hydroxybutyrate, respectively (172, 173). Biochemical reactions for multiple newly described Enterobacter spp., including E. bugandensis and E. massiliensis, have been published (174, 175).

For practical reasons, multiple species ofEnterobacter (E. asburiae, E. bugandensis, E. cancerogenus, E. cloacae and its subspecies, E. hormaechei and its subspecies, E. kobei, and E. ludwigii) are often reported in the medical record as E. cloacae complex because they have similar biochemical reactions and are of similar diagnostic importance (79). Multiple diagnostic platforms may not be capable of distinguishing between the species within the complex, including phenotypic commercial platforms as well as MALDI-TOF MS (176, 177). Different testing platforms may have different capabilities of resolving the members of the complex, so the clinical report from the laboratory should be consistent with the specific manufacturer’s guidance. Other species of Enterobacter that also have sequence similarity to E. cloacae, but which are not isolated as frequently, might be reported as Enterobacter species, unless sequencing analysis is clinically warranted.

sect1.title: Cronobacter
sect1.para: Cronobacter organisms form either dry or mucoid colonies, smooth and irregularly round colonies, or rough and wrinkled colonies, which are difficult to remove from the agar surface. About 80% of strains produce a yellow pigment at room temperature. Biotyping was initially proposed as a means of identifying Cronobacter spp. but should no longer be followed given that DNA sequence-based (including WGS) studies have revealed that the biotyping scheme is in considerable variance with the known genus phylogeny and serves no useful purpose.

The API20E and ID32E commercial kits were updated in 2015, following the 2007 taxonomic revision, and no longer use the former name ofE. sakazakii. Despite the updates, in one study that tested more than 240 strains of Cronobacter, only about 82% and 43% were correctly identified to the genus level with specific versions of the API20E and ID32E kits, respectively (178). Identification to the species level was even more problematic. In the same study, the VITEK GN cards identified all Cronobacter strains as “C. sakazakii group”; unfortunately, Franconibacter isolates were also identified as belonging to this group. Therefore, commercially available biochemical assays may not sufficiently identify Cronobacter isolates to the species level, and Cronobacter spp. are at times mistakenly identified as other genera; therefore, molecular methods, including the use of MALDI-TOF MS, with the most up-to-date databases are suggested if available (179–181).

A PCR-based method targeting theompA gene accurately identified the Cronobacter isolates, but only to the genus level. 16S rRNA gene sequencing of the genus Cronobacter is not reliable for all species due to their close genetic relationships, in particular between C. sakazakii and C. malonaticus (105, 182, 183). Instead, a number of molecular methods have been developed, improving detection of Cronobacter, the most useful being the sequencing of the housekeeping gene fusA, which forms part of the online MLST scheme (https://pubMLST.org/organisms/cronobacter-spp) and the phylogeny of which matches the whole-genome phylogeny (105).

sect1.title: Citrobacter
sect1.para: Citrobacter produces smooth, convex colonies that resemble those of other members of Enterobacteriaceae. Variable lactose fermentation reaction and a result of Alk/A or A/A on Kligler iron agar with H2S production in C. freundii may make differentiation from Salmonella difficult. Several other Citrobacter species are also able to produce H2S, and these unusual biotypes have variable phenotypic and antigenic characteristics resembling those of Salmonella or E. coli (184). Therefore, the inability of MALDI-TOF MS to distinguish Citrobacter from Salmonella is not infrequent even with up-to-date databases. Automated identification systems, such as the Phoenix identification system (Becton, Dickinson, Franklin Lakes, NJ) and API20E, have been useful for differentiation (185, 186). A quick approach to definitively identify an isolate as belonging to Citrobacter could also include screening agars such as urea agar slants and growth in potassium cyanide (KCN). Biochemical reactions comparing the more newly described Citrobacter spp. to the established species have been published (140). Serotyping of Citrobacter spp. with Salmonella agglutinins may also yield false-positive results (187). For practical reasons, multiple species of Citrobacter (C. braakii, C. freundii, C. gillenii, C. murliniae, C. rodentium, C. sedlakii, C. werkmanii, and C. youngae) are often reported to the medical record as C. freundii complex because they have similar biochemical reactions and are of similar diagnostic importance. Multiple diagnostic platforms may not be capable of identifying newly described species or distinguishing between the species within the complex.

sect1.title: Other Enterobacteriaceae
sect1.para: Kluyvera may be identified only to the genus level by commercial phenotyping systems, which do not include all Kluyvera spp. in their databases. Biochemical tests that may be useful in species differentiation include indole (positive for K. ascorbata, K. cryocrescens, and K. georgiana; negative for K. intermedia and K. sichuanensis), VP (positive only for K. intermedia), ONPG (negative only for K. sichuanensis), lysine decarboxylase (positive for K. ascorbata, K. georgiana, and K. sichuanensis; negative for K. intermedia and usually for K. cryocrescens), ascorbate utilization (K. ascorbata and K. georgiana are positive while K. cryocrescens is negative), and growth on cefsulodin-irgasan-novobiocin (CIN) agar (K. ascorbata and K. georgiana are positive while K. cryocrescens is negative) (151, 188–190). Some strains of Leclercia adecarboxylata produce a nondiffusible yellow pigment, a feature shared by relatively few members of the Enterobacteriaceae. L. adecarboxylata is included in the databases of multiple commercial biochemical identification systems and can also be identified by MALDI-TOF MS; of note, however, the recently described species Leclercia pneumoniae (isolated from an infant with pneumonia and sepsis) was highly similar to L. adecarboxylata in terms of both its biochemical profile and mass spectrogram and is not yet included in commercial identification system databases (191).

Identification of the rarely isolatedLelliottia, Pluralibacter, and Kosakonia spp. may be difficult because of biochemical similarities to other Enterobacteriaceae and only recent inclusion in MALDI-TOF MS databases, with a subset of species having undergone clinical validation. Some species are included in commercial biochemical identification system databases, although the utilized nomenclature may be outdated. Additional members of the Enterobacteriaceae are listed in Table 1. Some of the newer MALDI-TOF MS databases, especially the research-use-only collections, have a more extensive list of acceptable organisms than traditional biochemical systems. The classification of species is dynamic, and the databases are being updated frequently, so laboratory personnel must be aware of how their systems handle the less common organisms. Many but not all genera are included in the databases; however, in some cases, species within the genera may not be distinguishable.

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid-Based Identification
sect1.para: Information on molecular identification techniques is available elsewhere in thisManual. For many laboratories, the primary methods of molecular identification for Enterobacteriaceae include multiplex PCR, nucleic acid probe-based methods, and gene sequencing. Multiplex PCR and nucleic acid probe-based panels for the identification of organisms from positive blood cultures can identify many Enterobacteriaceae discussed in this chapter as well as selected resistance markers with high confidence (192–194). For example, among other targets, the VERIGENE BC-GN (Luminex, Austin, TX) can detect K. pneumoniae, K. oxytoca, Enterobacter spp., Citrobacter spp., blaCTX-M, blaKPC, blaNDM, blaOXA, blaIMP, and blaVIM; the BioFire FilmArray BCID2 (bioMérieux, Durham, NC) can detect K. pneumoniae group, K. oxytoca, K. aerogenes, Enterobacter cloacae complex, blaCTX-M, blaKPC, blaNDM, blaOXA-48-like, blaIMP, blaVIM, and mcr-1; and the GenMark ePlex BCID-GN can detect K. pneumoniae group, K. oxytoca, Enterobacter cloacae complex, Enterobacter (non-E. cloacae complex), Cronobacter sakazakii, Citrobacter spp., blaCTX-M, blaKPC, blaNDM, blaOXA-48-like, blaIMP, and blaVIM. These assays are discussed in more detail in the chapter Laboratory Detection of Bacteremia and Fungemia of this Manual. Multiplex PCR panels for use with lower respiratory tract specimens that include Enterobacteriaceae and relevant resistance genes among their targets have also recently become available (195, 196). These approaches do not aid in the identification of rare or otherwise difficult-to-identify organisms from other sources.

Many laboratories utilize partial 16S rRNA (~500-bp) gene sequencing to identifyEnterobacteriaceae (25), for which the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) provides useful information, including guidelines with suggested cutoff values for percent identity scores and identification algorithms (169). However, some genera within the family Enterobacteriaceae are identical within this gene; as such, partial 16S rRNA gene sequences may not reliably distinguish closely related genera or may not identify organisms to the species level, and examination of different 16S rRNA gene variable regions may be optimal for differentiation of various Enterobacteriaceae (25). Both public and commercial databases are available for the evaluation and comparison of gene sequence data. Databases may be noncurated or curated, and curation may occur manually or via algorithm-based methods. Frequently used public databases include NCBI, RDPII (https://rdp.cme.msu.edu/), leBIBI (https://umr5558-bibiserv.univ-lyon1.fr/lebibi/lebibi.cgi), Greengenes (https://greengenes.secondgenome.com), and SILVA (https://arb-silva.de). Identification of Enterobacteriaceae using rRNA gene sequences is discussed further elsewhere in this Manual.

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: The ability to trace the spread of nosocomial pathogens in outbreaks caused byEnterobacteriaceae has become a major responsibility for the laboratory. Chapters in this Manual devoted to outbreaks and epidemiology provide useful information on the molecular epidemiology of enteric outbreaks. Molecular techniques that target a limited portion of the bacterial genome, including plasmid analysis, ribotyping, pulsed-field gel electrophoresis, and various PCR methods, can have satisfactory discriminatory ability, depending on the details of the outbreak, with some working better for a specific genus or species than others (197, 198).

As mentioned above, MLST is a sequence-based typing method that analyzes fragments of selected, conserved housekeeping gene loci and is ideal for tracking certain clones or sequence types (STs) over time and to show common ancestry lineages among bacteria (14, 199). MLST has been responsible for identifying certain successful international STs among K. pneumoniae isolates, i.e., ST16 with blaCTX-M genes (200) and ST258 with blaKPC genes (201, 202), and C. sakazakii clonal complex ST4, associated with neonatal meningitis (105). International open-access databases supporting an increasing range of organisms include http://pubMLST.org and http://bigsdb.pasteur.fr/. MLST does not have the discriminatory power to assess relatedness of bacteria within a ST, however, and so other sequence-based strain typing methods may be needed for applications that require higher resolution (198).

MALDI-TOF MS has emerged as a potential means of rapid typing for some organisms, and is an appealing approach in terms of simplicity, speed, and cost, especially as MALDI-TOF MS is now a routine method of bacterial identification in many clinical laboratories. Studies using MALDI-TOF MS for strain typing have utilized heterogeneous methodologies, and variable success has been observed (203). Among the Enterobacteriaceae covered in this chapter, typing has been most frequently attempted for Klebsiella spp., with variable success (204–207). Further research on the performance and ability of MALDI-TOF MS is needed to differentiate relatedness.

The high resolution obtained with WGS has the ability to identify single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) between isolates, and this has made it possible to reconstruct and redefine transmission pathways in outbreak situations (201). In one prominent example, Snitkin and colleagues used WGS to gain insight into why an outbreak due to carbapenem-resistant K. pneumoniae progressed despite early implementation of infection control procedures (208). Integrated genomic and epidemiological analysis traced the outbreak to three independent transmissions from a single patient who was discharged three weeks before the next case became clinically apparent. They were also able to identify several unexpected transmission routes. Since this case, WGS has been used to characterize other significant multidrug-resistant Klebsiella outbreaks around the world (209–211), and the number of publications describing the use of WGS for outbreak investigations has rapidly increased. The integration of genomic and epidemiological data can facilitate the control of nosocomial transmission in a real-time fashion, as can be demonstrated at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pathogens. Recent studies have also demonstrated the ability of prospective WGS approaches to detect unrecognized nosocomial spread of multidrug-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (212, 213) and to beneficially impact infection prevention efforts in the hospital setting (214). With decreased costs and more user-friendly bioinformatics programs, WGS has emerged as the new gold standard for outbreak investigations. Further study of the SNP thresholds that should be used to define clonality in investigations of Enterobacteriaceae outbreaks is warranted.

Strain typing using clustered regular interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)–CRISPR-associated gene (cas) array profiling has been reported as another method for discriminating strains within a ST. Because CRISPR arrays reflect the acquisition of DNA over time through exposure to phages and plasmids, these arrays may differ between closely related bacterial strains, allowing the use of these loci for molecular subtyping. Among the organisms presented in this chapter, exploration of this technique has thus far been most developed for Cronobacter spp. (103). The utility of CRISPR-cas array profiling for typing may vary across members of the family Enterobacteriaceae; for example, not all Klebsiella pneumoniae genomes contain the CRISPR-cas system (215), and some spacers may be conserved between K. pneumoniae strains belonging to different STs (216).

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITY
sect2.para: Several species described in this chapter have intrinsic resistance to commonly used antimicrobial agents. Intrinsic resistance inK. pneumoniae due to presence of chromosomal SHV-1 penicillinase has been recognized for several decades (217). Class C serine β-lactamases (AmpC) are produced by several members of Enterobacteriaceae commonly referred to by the acronym SPICE/MYSPACE (218). Intrinsic resistance to cephalosporins in them is due to either inducible or stably derepressed chromosomal AmpC. The potential of induction of AmpC varies within the different bacterial genera but may be clinically significant in isolates of E. cloacae complex, K. aerogenes, and C. freundii complex.

Acquired resistance in Gram-negative pathogens is a substantial threat to global health and economy; specifically, resistance to broad-spectrum β-lactam agents significantly complicates treatment and is associated with considerably higher morbidity and mortality, emphasizing the need to control the spread of these pathogens (219, 220). Recent findings show a steady and alarming increase in resistance rates among K. pneumoniae isolates to four major antimicrobial classes, i.e., third-generation cephalosporins, aminoglycosides, carbapenems, and fluoroquinolones, which is attributed to its remarkable ability to capture and maintain plasmids from multiple sources (221, 222). Due to its ubiquitous distribution and high diversity of acquired antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes, K. pneumoniae has the potential to become a key amplifier and spreader of these genes (222). The most common carbapenemase, which bears its name (KPC), mobile quinolone resistance genes qnrA and qnrB, and mcr-1 are examples of plasmid-mediated resistance genes that have been found in K. pneumoniae and are now widespread among Gram-negative bacteria (222). Available data indicate a complicated epidemiology of K. pneumoniae circulating genotypes and the spread of diverse clones, such as the globally disseminated ST258 K. pneumoniae, ST14 and ST231 K. pneumoniae in South Asia, and K. pneumoniae clone ST307 in South Africa. The increased prevalence of blaNDM, blaOXA-48-like, and other carbapenemase genes in successful clones that are reported in outbreaks is particularly concerning (63, 220, 223, 224). Increasing resistance has culminated in the emergence of pan-resistant strains of K. pneumoniae for which there are few therapeutic options (225–227).

While carbapenem-resistantK. pneumoniae presents the most serious AMR threat among Enterobacteriaceae, other species can demonstrate resistance to several antimicrobial agents. Notably, K. aerogenes, E. cloacae complex, and C. freundii have intrinsic resistance to first-generation cephalosporins due to the presence of chromosomal AmpC β-lactamase; additionally, some species have the ability to modulate these mechanisms (98, 228–230). Selection of AmpC mutants, stable derepression of the chromosomally mediated inducible cephalosporinases, or plasmid-mediated ampC genes can lead to resistance to cephalosporins. Resistance during therapy with empiric antibiotics such as cephalosporins due to AmpC induction is of particular concern in E. cloacae, K. aerogenes, and C. freundii (227). Membrane-associated mechanisms of resistance including alterations in porin expression and multidrug efflux pump activities can also lead to nonsusceptibility to β-lactams including carbapenems as well as fluoroquinolones in these species (98, 228–230). Frequently, plasmids encoding β-lactamase enzymes also carry resistance genes for aminoglycosides, quinolones, and other antimicrobials (231).

Plasmid-mediated resistance to the polymyxins, conferred by themcr genes in the Enterobacterales (232), is especially concerning, as in recent years colistin has been a last line of defense against multidrug-resistant (MDR) Gram-negative bacteria. Since the initial report of mcr-1 in 2016, ten homologues of mcr have been described (233, 234). These plasmids have been detected in several members of Enterobacterales described in this chapter, including Enterobacter spp., K. oxytoca, K. pneumoniae, Cronobacter spp., and C. freundii (233).

Several new antimicrobial agents, specifically, new β-lactamase inhibitor (BLI) combinations, as well as the novel cephalosporins and tetracycline derivatives, are promising, as they provide therapeutic options for difficult-to-treat MDR Gram-negative infections. Differences in the spectrum of activity and efficacy exist for these newer antimicrobial agents, depending on the resistance mechanisms present in the organisms. Therefore, rapid and accurate detection of phenotypic resistance and its underlying mechanism, especially for the β-lactamase producers, greatly assists in proper management of these infections (235, 236). Manufacturers of automated antimicrobial susceptibility testing may not have updated panels available that include newer agents. Laboratories may need to verify/validate susceptibility testing to these drugs as interpretive breakpoints become available and if testing is warranted for resistant isolates. Laboratories can use genotypic and phenotypic methods to detect mechanisms of resistance, especially production of carbapenemases and extended-spectrum β-lactamases (ESBLs). Phenotypic assays are valuable for determining the actual activity of the organism in the presence of an antimicrobial. Phenotypic confirmation of carbapenemases detected by molecular methods may be needed, as there can be discordance between phenotypic antimicrobial susceptibility test results and molecular detection of carbapenemases. These are often due to overproduction of AmpC β-lactamases but can also be due to inactive enzymes caused by mutations in the β-lactamase genes. It is important that clinical laboratories have procedures in place to resolve such discrepancies in order to aid management of infections (237–239). The methods for detection of antimicrobial susceptibility and for determination of mechanisms of resistance are discussed in detail in chapters devoted to these topics.

sect1.title: Antimicrobial Resistance in Miscellaneous Enterobacteriaceae
sect1.para: Susceptibility results for uncommon species ofKlebsiella, Enterobacter, and Citrobacter are similar to those of conventional species within these genera (229). Susceptibilities of other Enterobacterales vary from isolate to isolate. In such cases, laboratories can use the breakpoints established for the Enterobacterales unless specific exclusions are listed in CLSI document M100. Moreover, it is important to note that this information changes with updates in taxonomy and as the published literature evolves; therefore, document M100 must be reviewed on an annual basis.

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: When commercial systems identify species included in this chapter with a high level of accuracy (>90% probability), the identification is probably reliable. However, for organisms isolated from sterile sites that are identified with a probability of <90%, the isolate should be confirmed by conventional or molecular methods or sent to a reference laboratory using these techniques. Using the College of American Pathologists proficiency testing summary as an indicator, slightly less than half of responding laboratories use MALDI-TOF MS for identification, indicating that more than half rely on commercial phenotypic/biochemical systems (240). A small number of laboratories listed API20E as the testing method and fewer than 5% used sequencing for the identifications of the proficiency testing samples; therefore, the caution noted throughout the chapter on careful identification at the bench is warranted. In the interim, the isolate may be reported to the physician with a presumptive identification. Many species described in this chapter are frequent pathogens and are reliably identified; however, rare species that are identified with low probabilities should always be sent to a reference laboratory accompanied by a brief history for clinically significant infections.

The clinical laboratory acts as an early warning system, alerting the medical community to new resistance mechanisms present in clinically important bacteria. The detection of antimicrobial-resistant organisms by laboratories is a critical step required for appropriate management of patients and infection prevention and control efforts. An increasing number of patients are infected or colonized withEnterobacterales possessing ESBLs and carbapenemases, and they serve as reservoirs for transmission of these enzymes within and between health care institutions. The ability to recognize these isolates is critical not only for patient care but also to prevent the emergence of pan-resistant strains.

Culture-independent methods are the hope on the horizon, including metagenomic next-generation sequencing of specimens and plasma cell-free DNA, such as the commercially available Karius company testing (241–243). Although Gamie et al. reported that the metagenomic approach inspired cautious optimism for joint infection diagnostics (244), others warn that there are still limited data for real-life performance of these methods. Certainly, there are challenges and limitations for these new methods to offer them as routine, cost-effective approaches, and quality control and proficiency testing are not yet standardized (245–248).

The presence of carbapenemases (especially enzymes encoded by plasmid-borne genes) inKlebsiella and Enterobacter spp. can indicate an infection control emergency, and clinical microbiology laboratories should be able to rapidly detect these enzymes among members of the Enterobacterales (44–48). This is a critical step required for appropriate management of patients and infection prevention and control efforts. As discussed, a number of phenotypic and molecular methods are available to screen for resistant Enterobacterales, and research is ongoing to understand in more detail the mechanisms of horizontal transfer of the resistance plasmids and to identify the factors most important for controlling worldwide spread of resistant organisms (219).

Given the spread of resistance in these bacteria, it is essential for clinicians to stay up to date on the latest treatment recommendations available (227, 249, 250) and to appreciate that outcomes are not necessarily the same across different regions (251). Research and development efforts continue to find new drugs to treat these bacteria (252–255).

Given the increasing frequency of multidrug-resistantEnterobacteriaceae, more investigators are exploring alternative types of treatment, such as monoclonal antibodies directed against bacteria (256), CRISPR-Cas-based approaches (257), and phage therapy (258, 259), in addition to ongoing work on improvement of the traditional chemical antimicrobials used most frequently today (260).

Beyond efficient identification of these bacteria and effective treatment, future work will also continue to explore the hypothesized role of some of these bacteria in chronic disease and malignancies (4, 261, 262).
We thank previous authors of this chapter for laying the foundation for the description of these genera: Stephen Forsythe, Sharon Abbott, Johann Pitout, Angella Charnot-Katsikas, and Kevin Alby.
